_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

CALIFORNIA ACCIDENTAL 

RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

E&J GALLO WINERY - FRESNO

JULY 2012









    The E & J Gallo Fresno Winery is located at 5610 East Olive Avenue in Fresno, California.  The facility crushes grapes in order to produce wine, distilled spirits, and juice for concentrate.  These products are stored prior to shipment to other Gallo facilities for further processing and distribution.



    The facility operates anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems to provide product cooling.  Refrigeration systems have storage vessels (receivers) d to contain all the liquid ammonia in the system, with additional capacity for thermal expansion.



    The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop heat transfer system.  Ammonia moves through the system due to pressure differences produced by the compressors.  A brief description of the ammonia refrigeration cycle follows:



Refrigeration cycle follows:



1.    The receiver vessel stores liquid ammonia under pressure.  High pressure liquid ammonia flows from the receiver through liquid lines to the expansion valve, which partitions the pressure and temperature.  Liquid ammonia at reduced pressure and temperature is then piped in to the chiller shell.  

2.    Product is circulated through sealed stainless steel tubing within the chiller shell.  Heat from the warm product transfers through the tubing walls to the cooler refrigerant, causing liquid refrigerant to boil off as low pressure vapor.  The rate of vaporization, and thereby the cooling of product, is determined by the amount of pressure in the chiller as controlled by a back pressure regulator, and suction from the compressors.  

3.    The compressors draw the low pressure vapor from the chiller, compress it into high pressure vapor, and discharge it to the evaporative condenser (cooling tower).

4.    In the evaporative condenser, ammonia vapor flows through tubing which is sprayed with water and located within fan driven air flow to promote cooling.

The ammonia vapor transfers heat through the tubing walls to the cooling water.  The ammonia condenses back to a liquid which drains by gravity to the receiver vessel.  



In addition to ammonia refrigeration systems, the facility uses anhydrous ammonia to adjust the pH of process water being discharged to the Fresno POTW.



 

The Winery maintains storage vessels of liquid sulfur dioxide used as a stabilizing agent during processing activities.



         Ammonia Systems (Processes) - Federal RMP Program Level 3:



        Ammonia Supply Tank at Main Wastewater Sump

              Capacity 10,060 gal x 80% = 8048 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 41,447 lbs.

                   

         Refrigeration system #1

             Capacity 2829 gal x 80% = 2263 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 11,655 lbs.



             Refrigeration System #2 

             Capacity 2851 gal x 80% = 2281 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 11,746 lbs.



             Refrigeration System #3

             Capacity 3000 gal x 80% = 2400 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 12,360 lbs.



              Refrigeration Systems #8, 9, 10 & 11

             Capacity 4808 gal x 80% = 3846 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 19,809 lbs.



             Refrigeration Systems #13 & 16    

             Capacity 5839 gal x 80% = 4671 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 24,057 lbs.



             Refrigeration Systems #14 & 15

             Capacity 6020 gal x 80% = 4816 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 24,802 lbs.



         Refrigeration System # 17,18 & 19

             Capacity 12,807.5 gal x 80% = 10,246.2 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 52,768 lbs.





        

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY FOR RMP COVERED PROCESSES



Ammonia



In the five years prior to this submission, there have been no accidents or releases of ammonia at E & J Gallo Winery, Fresno that exceed the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the past five years (June 2007 - June 2012). TOXIC 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION



The E & J Gallo Winery employs RETA-trained/certified refrigeration mechanics, supported by engineering staff.  The refrigeration system is maintained through the scheduled implementation of a sc

heduled preventative maintenance program based upon standard industry practices. Employees required to operate ammonia refrigeration equipment receive training specific to their assigned duties and hold the appropriate RETA certifications.







EMERGENCY RESPONSE



In the event of a reportable chemical release, notifications will be made to the appropriate agencies including the Fresno County Department of Health Services, the State Office of Emergency Services (as directed by the Fresno County CUPA), and the Federal National Response Center (as appropriate). 



Gallo management and site representatives will respond to the emergency within their level of training and will partner with public emergency response personnel in mitigating the problem.  





MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



The Management of Change Procedure will require evaluation of new construction and modifications to existing ammonia systems to determine the likelihood of an effect on ammonia safety.  Changes expected to have a significant safety effect on quantity, systems, or procedures will be referred to the appropriate Risk Management Program team for further study. 





COMPLIANCE AUDITS



The facility evaluates compliance with the Risk Management Program (RMP) once every three years, at a minimum, to verify that the procedures and practices complying with the RMP program are adequate and is being followed.  The compliance audits are conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. The compliance audit deficiencies are reviewed by a cross-functional team; plan and timetable for resolution of action items are established.   The Compliance Audit will be maintained by the Corporate Legal Department. Resulting action items from the audits will be maintained at the site EHS office. The last compliance audit was conducted by SCS Tracer Environmental May 31, 2011 through June 1, 2011. 





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS





Ammonia Refrigeration Systems

The most current process hazard analysis (PHA) update was completed February 22-23, 2011 for the refrigeration ammonia systems and was facilitated by SCS Tracer Environmental.  The PHA was conducted over 2 days and the PHA team was comprised of employees with expertise in the following disciples:  instrumentation, refrigeration maintenance, refrigeration operations, safety and health management with extensively training in PHA methodology and refrigeration systems, and environmental.  



The PHA update addressed the following: 



?    Hazards of the process

?    Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships such as appropriate application of detection methodologies to provide early warning of releases

?    Consequences of failures of engineering and administrative controls

?    Stationary source site map

?    Human factors

?    Qualitative evaluation of a range of possible safety and health effects of failures of controls

?    Consideration of external events, including seismic events, if applicable.  PHAs completed for other programs where external events were not considered shall be updated to include external events



Approximately 132 man-hours were spent on the ammonia PHAs. Approximately 8 recommendations resulting from the PHAs were evaluated and addressed by a Process Safety Management/Risk Management Plan (PSM/RMP) steering committee which included the senior managers on site.   Resolution of the PHA action items included the following documentation:



?    Name of individual assigned action item

?    Description of action to be taken

?    Due Date

?    Documentation associated with actions 

?    Communication of actions to operations, maintenance and other employees who work assignments are in the process 





PHAs are updated every five years; records associated with the PHAs are kept for the life of the process. 



An additional PHA was conducted for the newly installed Tower 19 on January 19, 2012 and was facilitated by SCS

Tracer Environmental.  The PHA team was comprised of employees with expertise in the following disciples:  instrumentation, refrigeration maintenance, refrigeration operations, engineering, system designers, risk management, safety and health management with extensively training in PHA methodology and refrigeration systems, and environmental.  



The PHA update addressed the following: 



?    Hazards of the process

?    Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships such as appropriate application of detection methodologies to provide early warning of releases

?    Consequences of failures of engineering and administrative controls

?    Stationary source site map

?    Human factors

?    Qualitative evaluation of a range of possible safety and health effects of failures of controls

?    Consideration of external events, including seismic events, if applicable.  PHAs completed for other programs where external events were not considered shall be updated to include external events



Approximately 114 man-hours were spent on the ammonia PHAs. Approximately 8 recommendations resulting from the PHAs were evaluated and addressed by a Process Safety Management/Risk Management Plan (PSM/RMP) steering committee which included the senior managers on site.   Resolution of the PHA action items included the following documentation:



?    Name of individual assigned action item

?    Description of action to be taken

?    Due Date

?    Documentation associated with actions 

?    Communication of actions to operations, maintenance and other employees who work assignments are in the process 





PHAs are updated every five years; records associated with the PHAs are kept for the life of the process.
